Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-Ids none Performs the operation on the unique resource IDs specified. Enter multiple resource IDs in comma-separated format. The `Ids` and `Name` parameters cannot be provided together. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-Name none Performs the operation on the unique name specified. false True (ByPropertyName, ByValue) None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None
-Versions none A list of versions. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • System.String

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
PS C:\> {{ Add example code here }}
{{ Add example description here }}

Top of page

Get-Pfa2SoftwareInstallation

List software upgrades

Displays a list of software upgrades. This returns both currently running and past upgrades.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2SoftwareInstallation [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Filter <String>] [-Ids <List<String>>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-Name <String>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-SoftwareIds <List<String>>] [-SoftwareNames <List<String>>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-Ids none Performs the operation on the unique resource IDs specified. Enter multiple resource IDs in comma-separated format. The `Ids` and `Name` parameters cannot be provided together. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-Name none Performs the operation on the unique name specified. false True (ByPropertyName, ByValue) None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-SoftwareIds none A list of software IDs. false False None
-SoftwareNames none A list of software names. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • System.String

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Syntax

Syntax

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-Name none Performs the operation on the unique name specified. false True (ByPropertyName, ByValue) None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None

Examples

Example 1 
@(Get-Pfa2Subnet -Array $Array).count
Get the number of subnet of FlashArray
Example 2 
Get-Pfa2Subnet -Array $Array -Name $Name
Get a subnet of FlashArray with a specific name

Get-Pfa2Support

List connection paths

Displays connection paths between the current array and each connected array.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2Support [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Filter <String>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None

Get-Pfa2SupportTest

List Pure Technical Services connection data

Displays information about whether the array can connect to Pure Technical Services by establishing a secure shell or secure HTTP connection and verifies that messages can be exchanged.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2SupportTest [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Filter <String>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [-TestType <String>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None
-TestType none Specifies the type of test. Valid values are `all`, `phonehome`, and `remote-assist`. If not specified, defaults to `all`. false False None

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • None

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
Get-Pfa2SupportTest -Array $Array
Get information about whether the array can connect to Pure Storage Support

Top of page

Get-Pfa2Volume

List volumes

Displays a list of volumes, including those pending eradication.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2Volume [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Destroyed <Boolean>] [-Filter <String>] [-Ids <List<String>>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-Name <String>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Destroyed none If set to `true`, lists only destroyed objects that are in the eradication pending state. If set to `false`, lists only objects that are not destroyed. For destroyed objects, the time remaining is displayed in seconds. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-Ids none Performs the operation on the unique resource IDs specified. Enter multiple resource IDs in comma-separated format. The `Ids` and `Name` parameters cannot be provided together. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-Name none Performs the operation on the unique name specified. false True (ByPropertyName, ByValue) None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • System.String

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
Get-Pfa2Volume -Array $Array
Get volumes from FlashArray
Example 2 
Get-Pfa2Volume -Array $Array | Where { $_.VolumeGroup.Name -eq $VolGroup.Name } | ForEach-Object {
Get all volume from FlashArray and locally filter and operate only on volumes whose VolumeGroup is $VolGroup.Name
Example 3 
Get-Pfa2Volume -Array $Array -Name $NewVolumeName
Get volume named $NewVolumeName
Example 4 
Get-Pfa2Volume -Array $Array -Limit $Limit
Get a limited set of volumes from FlashArray defined by $Limit (See -Offset)
Example 5 
Get-Pfa2Volume -Array $Array -Offset $Limit
Get all volumes from offset $Limit (See -Limit)
Example 6 
'*$($NamePrefix)*'" -Destroyed $False | Update-Pfa2Volume -Array $Array -Destroyed $True
Get all non-destroyed volumes from FlashArray using server side filtering (See `help About_Pfa2Filtering` on PowerShell) and destroy all at once using pipeline
Example 7 
'*$($NamePrefix)*'" -Destroyed $True | Remove-Pfa2Volume -Array $Array -Eradicate -Confirm:$false
Get all destroyed volumes using server side filtering and eradicate them
Example 8 
Get-Pfa2Volume -Array $Array -Filter "name = '$($Volumes[2].Name)'"
Get all volumes using server side filtering where name equals "$($Volumes[2].Name)". See `help About_Pfa2Filtering` on PowerShell window
Example 9 
Get-Pfa2Volume -Array $Array -Sort "provisioned"
Get all volumes on FlashArray with server side sorted list. Sorted by field "provisioned"
Example 10 
Get-Pfa2Volume
Get all volumes from FlashArray. Here the FlashArray authentication information is retrieved from Cache. Please see Connect-Pfa2Array
Example 11 
Get-Pfa2Volume -Filter "name ='$($prefix)*'"
Get all volumes from FlashArray with name $prefix using Server side filtering. Here the FlashArray authentication information is retrieved from Cache. Please see Connect-Pfa2Array
Example 12 
Get-Pfa2Volume -Filter "name ='$($prefix)*'" -Limit $limit
Get only a limited set of volumes from FlashArray with name $prefix using Server side filtering. The limit is defined by $Limit
Example 13 
Get-Pfa2Volume -Filter "name ='$($prefix)*'" -Limit $limit -Offset $offset
Get only a limited set of volumes from a given $offset from FlashArray with name $prefix using Server side filtering. The limit is defined by $Limit

Top of page

Get-Pfa2VolumeGroup

List volume groups

Returns a list of volume groups, including those pending eradication.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2VolumeGroup [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Destroyed <Boolean>] [-Filter <String>] [-Ids <List<String>>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-Name <String>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Destroyed none If set to `true`, lists only destroyed objects that are in the eradication pending state. If set to `false`, lists only objects that are not destroyed. For destroyed objects, the time remaining is displayed in seconds. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-Ids none Performs the operation on the unique resource IDs specified. Enter multiple resource IDs in comma-separated format. The `Ids` and `Name` parameters cannot be provided together. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-Name none Performs the operation on the unique name specified. false True (ByPropertyName, ByValue) None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • System.String

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
Get-Pfa2VolumeGroup -Array $Array | Where { $_.Name.Contains($prefix) }
Get all volume group from FlashArray and locally filter where name contains a prefix
Example 2 
Get-Pfa2VolumeGroup -Array $Array -Name $VolumeGroup.Name
Get volume group named $VolumeGroup.Name

Top of page

Get-Pfa2VolumeGroupPerformance

List volume group performance data

Returns real-time and historical performance data, real-time latency data, and average I/O sizes for each volume group and for the total of all volume groups across the entire array.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2VolumeGroupPerformance [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Destroyed <Boolean>] [-EndTime <Int64>] [-Filter <String>] [-Ids <List<String>>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-Name <String>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-Resolution <Int64>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [-StartTime <Int64>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Destroyed none If set to `true`, lists only destroyed objects that are in the eradication pending state. If set to `false`, lists only objects that are not destroyed. For destroyed objects, the time remaining is displayed in seconds. false False None
-EndTime none Displays historical performance data for the specified time window, where `StartTime` is the beginning of the time window, and `EndTime` is the end of the time window. The `StartTime` and `EndTime` parameters are specified in milliseconds since the UNIX epoch. If `StartTime` is not specified, the start time will default to one resolution before the end time, meaning that the most recent sample of performance data will be displayed. If `EndTime`is not specified, the end time will default to the current time. Include the `Resolution` parameter to display the performance data at the specified resolution. If not specified, `Resolution` defaults to the lowest valid resolution. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-Ids none Performs the operation on the unique resource IDs specified. Enter multiple resource IDs in comma-separated format. The `Ids` and `Name` parameters cannot be provided together. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-Name none Performs the operation on the unique name specified. false True (ByPropertyName, ByValue) None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-Resolution none The number of milliseconds between samples of historical data. For array-wide performance metrics (`/arrays/performance` endpoint), valid values are `1000` (1 second), `30000` (30 seconds), `300000` (5 minutes), `1800000` (30 minutes), `7200000` (2 hours), `28800000` (8 hours), and `86400000` (24 hours). For performance metrics on storage objects (`<object name>/performance` endpoint), such as volumes, valid values are `30000` (30 seconds), `300000` (5 minutes), `1800000` (30 minutes), `7200000` (2 hours), `28800000` (8 hours), and `86400000` (24 hours). For space metrics, (`<object name>/space` endpoint), valid values are `300000` (5 minutes), `1800000` (30 minutes), `7200000` (2 hours), `28800000` (8 hours), and `86400000` (24 hours). Include the `StartTime` parameter to display the performance data starting at the specified start time. If `StartTime` is not specified, the start time will default to one resolution before the end time, meaning that the most recent sample of performance data will be displayed. Include the `EndTime` parameter to display the performance data until the specified end time. If `EndTime`is not specified, the end time will default to the current time. If the `Resolution` parameter is not specified but either the `StartTime` or `EndTime` parameter is, then `Resolution` will default to the lowest valid resolution. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None
-StartTime none Displays historical performance data for the specified time window, where `StartTime` is the beginning of the time window, and `EndTime` is the end of the time window. The `StartTime` and `EndTime` parameters are specified in milliseconds since the UNIX epoch. If `StartTime` is not specified, the start time will default to one resolution before the end time, meaning that the most recent sample of performance data will be displayed. If `EndTime`is not specified, the end time will default to the current time. Include the `Resolution` parameter to display the performance data at the specified resolution. If not specified, `Resolution` defaults to the lowest valid resolution. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • System.String

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
Get-Pfa2VolumeGroupPerformance -Array $Array -Name $VolumeGroup.Name
Get performance data of the volume group named $VolumeGroup.Name

Top of page

Get-Pfa2VolumeGroupSpace

List volume group space information

Returns the provisioned (virtual) size and physical storage consumption data for each volume group.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2VolumeGroupSpace [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Destroyed <Boolean>] [-EndTime <Int64>] [-Filter <String>] [-Ids <List<String>>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-Name <String>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-Resolution <Int64>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [-StartTime <Int64>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Destroyed none If set to `true`, lists only destroyed objects that are in the eradication pending state. If set to `false`, lists only objects that are not destroyed. For destroyed objects, the time remaining is displayed in seconds. false False None
-EndTime none Displays historical performance data for the specified time window, where `StartTime` is the beginning of the time window, and `EndTime` is the end of the time window. The `StartTime` and `EndTime` parameters are specified in milliseconds since the UNIX epoch. If `StartTime` is not specified, the start time will default to one resolution before the end time, meaning that the most recent sample of performance data will be displayed. If `EndTime`is not specified, the end time will default to the current time. Include the `Resolution` parameter to display the performance data at the specified resolution. If not specified, `Resolution` defaults to the lowest valid resolution. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-Ids none Performs the operation on the unique resource IDs specified. Enter multiple resource IDs in comma-separated format. The `Ids` and `Name` parameters cannot be provided together. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-Name none Performs the operation on the unique name specified. false True (ByPropertyName, ByValue) None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-Resolution none The number of milliseconds between samples of historical data. For array-wide performance metrics (`/arrays/performance` endpoint), valid values are `1000` (1 second), `30000` (30 seconds), `300000` (5 minutes), `1800000` (30 minutes), `7200000` (2 hours), `28800000` (8 hours), and `86400000` (24 hours). For performance metrics on storage objects (`<object name>/performance` endpoint), such as volumes, valid values are `30000` (30 seconds), `300000` (5 minutes), `1800000` (30 minutes), `7200000` (2 hours), `28800000` (8 hours), and `86400000` (24 hours). For space metrics, (`<object name>/space` endpoint), valid values are `300000` (5 minutes), `1800000` (30 minutes), `7200000` (2 hours), `28800000` (8 hours), and `86400000` (24 hours). Include the `StartTime` parameter to display the performance data starting at the specified start time. If `StartTime` is not specified, the start time will default to one resolution before the end time, meaning that the most recent sample of performance data will be displayed. Include the `EndTime` parameter to display the performance data until the specified end time. If `EndTime`is not specified, the end time will default to the current time. If the `Resolution` parameter is not specified but either the `StartTime` or `EndTime` parameter is, then `Resolution` will default to the lowest valid resolution. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None
-StartTime none Displays historical performance data for the specified time window, where `StartTime` is the beginning of the time window, and `EndTime` is the end of the time window. The `StartTime` and `EndTime` parameters are specified in milliseconds since the UNIX epoch. If `StartTime` is not specified, the start time will default to one resolution before the end time, meaning that the most recent sample of performance data will be displayed. If `EndTime`is not specified, the end time will default to the current time. Include the `Resolution` parameter to display the performance data at the specified resolution. If not specified, `Resolution` defaults to the lowest valid resolution. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • System.String

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
Get-Pfa2VolumeGroupSpace -Array $Array -Ids $VolumeGroup.Id
Get space data of the volume group having id of $VolumeGroup.Id

Top of page

Get-Pfa2VolumeGroupVolume

List volume groups with volumes

Returns a list of volume groups that contain volumes.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2VolumeGroupVolume [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Filter <String>] [-GroupIds <List<String>>] [-GroupNames <List<String>>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-MemberIds <List<String>>] [-MemberNames <List<String>>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-GroupIds none A list of group IDs. false False None
-GroupNames none Performs the operation on the unique group name specified. Examples of groups include host groups, pods, protection groups, and volume groups. Enter multiple names in comma-separated format. For example, `hgroup01,hgroup02`. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-MemberIds none A list of member IDs. false False None
-MemberNames none Performs the operation on the unique member name specified. Examples of members include volumes, hosts, and host groups. Enter multiple names in comma-separated format. For example, `vol01,vol02`. false False None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • None

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
Get-Pfa2VolumeGroupVolume -Array $Array -GroupIds $VolumeGroup.Id
Get volumes that are added to volume group of which the group id is $VolumeGroup.Id

Top of page

Get-Pfa2VolumePerformance

List volume performance data

Returns real-time and historical performance data, real-time latency data, and average I/O sizes for each volume and for the total of all volumes across the entire array.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2VolumePerformance [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Destroyed <Boolean>] [-EndTime <Int64>] [-Filter <String>] [-Ids <List<String>>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-Name <String>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-Resolution <Int64>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [-StartTime <Int64>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Destroyed none If set to `true`, lists only destroyed objects that are in the eradication pending state. If set to `false`, lists only objects that are not destroyed. For destroyed objects, the time remaining is displayed in seconds. false False None
-EndTime none Displays historical performance data for the specified time window, where `StartTime` is the beginning of the time window, and `EndTime` is the end of the time window. The `StartTime` and `EndTime` parameters are specified in milliseconds since the UNIX epoch. If `StartTime` is not specified, the start time will default to one resolution before the end time, meaning that the most recent sample of performance data will be displayed. If `EndTime`is not specified, the end time will default to the current time. Include the `Resolution` parameter to display the performance data at the specified resolution. If not specified, `Resolution` defaults to the lowest valid resolution. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-Ids none Performs the operation on the unique resource IDs specified. Enter multiple resource IDs in comma-separated format. The `Ids` and `Name` parameters cannot be provided together. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-Name none Performs the operation on the unique name specified. false True (ByPropertyName, ByValue) None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-Resolution none The number of milliseconds between samples of historical data. For array-wide performance metrics (`/arrays/performance` endpoint), valid values are `1000` (1 second), `30000` (30 seconds), `300000` (5 minutes), `1800000` (30 minutes), `7200000` (2 hours), `28800000` (8 hours), and `86400000` (24 hours). For performance metrics on storage objects (`<object name>/performance` endpoint), such as volumes, valid values are `30000` (30 seconds), `300000` (5 minutes), `1800000` (30 minutes), `7200000` (2 hours), `28800000` (8 hours), and `86400000` (24 hours). For space metrics, (`<object name>/space` endpoint), valid values are `300000` (5 minutes), `1800000` (30 minutes), `7200000` (2 hours), `28800000` (8 hours), and `86400000` (24 hours). Include the `StartTime` parameter to display the performance data starting at the specified start time. If `StartTime` is not specified, the start time will default to one resolution before the end time, meaning that the most recent sample of performance data will be displayed. Include the `EndTime` parameter to display the performance data until the specified end time. If `EndTime`is not specified, the end time will default to the current time. If the `Resolution` parameter is not specified but either the `StartTime` or `EndTime` parameter is, then `Resolution` will default to the lowest valid resolution. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None
-StartTime none Displays historical performance data for the specified time window, where `StartTime` is the beginning of the time window, and `EndTime` is the end of the time window. The `StartTime` and `EndTime` parameters are specified in milliseconds since the UNIX epoch. If `StartTime` is not specified, the start time will default to one resolution before the end time, meaning that the most recent sample of performance data will be displayed. If `EndTime`is not specified, the end time will default to the current time. Include the `Resolution` parameter to display the performance data at the specified resolution. If not specified, `Resolution` defaults to the lowest valid resolution. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • System.String

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
Get-Pfa2VolumePerformance -Array $Array -Name $Volume.Name
Get volume performance statistics on FlashArray

Top of page

Get-Pfa2VolumePerformanceByArray

List volume performance data by array

Return real-time and historical performance data, real-time latency data, and average I/O size data. The data returned is for each volume on the current array and for each volume on any remote arrays that are visible to the current array. The data is grouped by individual volumes and as a total across all volumes on each array.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2VolumePerformanceByArray [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Destroyed <Boolean>] [-EndTime <Int64>] [-Filter <String>] [-Ids <List<String>>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-Name <String>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-Resolution <Int64>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [-StartTime <Int64>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Destroyed none If set to `true`, lists only destroyed objects that are in the eradication pending state. If set to `false`, lists only objects that are not destroyed. For destroyed objects, the time remaining is displayed in seconds. false False None
-EndTime none Displays historical performance data for the specified time window, where `StartTime` is the beginning of the time window, and `EndTime` is the end of the time window. The `StartTime` and `EndTime` parameters are specified in milliseconds since the UNIX epoch. If `StartTime` is not specified, the start time will default to one resolution before the end time, meaning that the most recent sample of performance data will be displayed. If `EndTime`is not specified, the end time will default to the current time. Include the `Resolution` parameter to display the performance data at the specified resolution. If not specified, `Resolution` defaults to the lowest valid resolution. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-Ids none Performs the operation on the unique resource IDs specified. Enter multiple resource IDs in comma-separated format. The `Ids` and `Name` parameters cannot be provided together. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-Name none Performs the operation on the unique name specified. false True (ByPropertyName, ByValue) None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-Resolution none The number of milliseconds between samples of historical data. For array-wide performance metrics (`/arrays/performance` endpoint), valid values are `1000` (1 second), `30000` (30 seconds), `300000` (5 minutes), `1800000` (30 minutes), `7200000` (2 hours), `28800000` (8 hours), and `86400000` (24 hours). For performance metrics on storage objects (`<object name>/performance` endpoint), such as volumes, valid values are `30000` (30 seconds), `300000` (5 minutes), `1800000` (30 minutes), `7200000` (2 hours), `28800000` (8 hours), and `86400000` (24 hours). For space metrics, (`<object name>/space` endpoint), valid values are `300000` (5 minutes), `1800000` (30 minutes), `7200000` (2 hours), `28800000` (8 hours), and `86400000` (24 hours). Include the `StartTime` parameter to display the performance data starting at the specified start time. If `StartTime` is not specified, the start time will default to one resolution before the end time, meaning that the most recent sample of performance data will be displayed. Include the `EndTime` parameter to display the performance data until the specified end time. If `EndTime`is not specified, the end time will default to the current time. If the `Resolution` parameter is not specified but either the `StartTime` or `EndTime` parameter is, then `Resolution` will default to the lowest valid resolution. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None
-StartTime none Displays historical performance data for the specified time window, where `StartTime` is the beginning of the time window, and `EndTime` is the end of the time window. The `StartTime` and `EndTime` parameters are specified in milliseconds since the UNIX epoch. If `StartTime` is not specified, the start time will default to one resolution before the end time, meaning that the most recent sample of performance data will be displayed. If `EndTime`is not specified, the end time will default to the current time. Include the `Resolution` parameter to display the performance data at the specified resolution. If not specified, `Resolution` defaults to the lowest valid resolution. false False None

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • System.String

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
Get-Pfa2VolumePerformanceByArray -Array $Array -Name $Volume.Name
Get volume performance statistics by array on FlashArray

List volumes that are members of protection groups

Returns a list of volume members that belong to one or more protection groups.

Syntax

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None

-GroupNames none Performs the operation on the unique group name specified. Examples of groups include host groups, pods, protection groups, and volume groups. Enter multiple names in comma-separated format. For example, `hgroup01,hgroup02`. false False None

The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None

For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. Get-Pfa2VolumeSnapshot

List volume snapshots

Return a list of volume snapshots, including those pending eradication.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2VolumeSnapshot [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Destroyed <Boolean>] [-Filter <String>] [-Ids <List<String>>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-Name <String>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [-SourceIds <List<String>>] [-SourceNames <List<String>>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Destroyed none If set to `true`, lists only destroyed objects that are in the eradication pending state. If set to `false`, lists only objects that are not destroyed. For destroyed objects, the time remaining is displayed in seconds. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-Ids none Performs the operation on the unique resource IDs specified. Enter multiple resource IDs in comma-separated format. The `Ids` and `Name` parameters cannot be provided together. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-Name none Performs the operation on the unique name specified. false True (ByPropertyName, ByValue) None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None
-SourceIds none Performs the operation on the source ID specified. Enter multiple source IDs in comma-separated format. false False None
-SourceNames none Performs the operation on the source name specified. Enter multiple source names in comma-separated format. For example, `name01,name02`. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • System.String

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
Get-Pfa2VolumeSnapshot -Array $Array -SourceNames $Volume.Name
Get all snapshots for volume $Volume.Name on FlashArray

Get-Pfa2VolumeSnapshotTags

List tags

Displays the list of tags.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2VolumeSnapshotTags [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Filter <String>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-ResourceDestroyed <Boolean>] [-ResourceIds <List<String>>] [-ResourceNames <List<String>>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-ResourceDestroyed none If set to `true`, returns only objects from destroyed resources. Returns an error if the name of a live resource is specified in the `ResourceNames` query parameter. If set to `false`, returns only objects from live resources. Returns an error if the name of a destroyed resource is specified in the `ResourceNames` query parameter. false False None
-ResourceIds none A list of resource IDs. The `ResourceIds` and `ResourceNames` parameters cannot be provided together. false False None
-ResourceNames none A list of resource names. The `ResourceIds` and `ResourceNames` parameters cannot be provided together. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • None

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
Get-Pfa2VolumeSnapshotTags -Array $Array -ResourceNames $Result.Name
Get all tags for volume snapshot with name $Result.Name on FlashArray
Example 2 
Get-Pfa2VolumeSnapshotTags -Array $Array
Get all tags for all volume snapshots on FlashArray

Get-Pfa2VolumeSpace

List volume space information

Returns the provisioned (virtual) size and physical storage consumption data for each volume.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2VolumeSpace [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Destroyed <Boolean>] [-EndTime <Int64>] [-Filter <String>] [-Ids <List<String>>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-Name <String>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-Resolution <Int64>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [-StartTime <Int64>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None

If the `Resolution` parameter is not specified but either the `StartTime` or `EndTime` parameter is, then `Resolution` will default to the lowest valid resolution. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. If `EndTime`is not specified, the end time will default to the current time. Include the `Resolution` parameter to display the performance data at the specified resolution. If not specified, `Resolution` defaults to the lowest valid resolution. false False None

Examples

Example 1 
Get-Pfa2VolumeSpace -Array $Array -Name $Volume.Name
Get volume space statistics on FlashArray

Top of page

Get-Pfa2VolumeTag

List tags

Displays the list of tags.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2VolumeTag [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Filter <String>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-ResourceDestroyed <Boolean>] [-ResourceIds <List<String>>] [-ResourceNames <List<String>>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-ResourceDestroyed none If set to `true`, returns only objects from destroyed resources. Returns an error if the name of a live resource is specified in the `ResourceNames` query parameter. If set to `false`, returns only objects from live resources. Returns an error if the name of a destroyed resource is specified in the `ResourceNames` query parameter. false False None
-ResourceIds none A list of resource IDs. The `ResourceIds` and `ResourceNames` parameters cannot be provided together. false False None
-ResourceNames none A list of resource names. The `ResourceIds` and `ResourceNames` parameters cannot be provided together. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • None

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
Get-Pfa2VolumeTag -Array $Array -ResourceNames $Volume.Name
Get all tags on volume $Volume.Name on FlashArray

Top of page

Get-Pfa2VolumeVolumeGroup

List volumes that are in volume groups

Returns a list of volumes that are in a volume group.

Syntax 

Get-Pfa2VolumeVolumeGroup [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Filter <String>] [-GroupIds <List<String>>] [-GroupNames <List<String>>] [-Limit <Int32>] [-MemberIds <List<String>>] [-MemberNames <List<String>>] [-Offset <Int32>] [-Sort <List<String>>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Filter none Narrows down the results to only the response objects that satisfy the filter criteria. false False None
-GroupIds none A list of group IDs. false False None
-GroupNames none Performs the operation on the unique group name specified. Examples of groups include host groups, pods, protection groups, and volume groups. Enter multiple names in comma-separated format. For example, `hgroup01,hgroup02`. false False None
-Limit none Limits the size of the response to the specified number of objects on each page. To return the total number of resources, set `limit=0`. The total number of resources is returned as a `TotalItemCount` value. If the page size requested is larger than the system maximum limit, the server returns the maximum limit, disregarding the requested page size. false False None
-MemberIds none A list of member IDs. false False None
-MemberNames none Performs the operation on the unique member name specified. Examples of members include volumes, hosts, and host groups. Enter multiple names in comma-separated format. For example, `vol01,vol02`. false False None
-Offset none The starting position based on the results of the query in relation to the full set of response objects returned. false False None
-Sort none Returns the response objects in the order specified. Set `Sort` to the name in the response by which to sort. Sorting can be performed on any of the names in the response, and the objects can be sorted in ascending or descending order. By default, the response objects are sorted in ascending order. To sort in descending order, append the minus sign (`-`) to the name. A single request can be sorted on multiple objects. For example, you can sort all volumes from largest to smallest volume size, and then sort volumes of the same size in ascending order by volume name. To sort on multiple names, list the names as comma-separated values. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • None

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
Get-Pfa2VolumeVolumeGroup -Array $Array -MemberIds $Volume.Id
Find VolumeGroups where a volume of which the id is $Volume.Id belongs.

Invoke-Pfa2CLICommand

Execute CLI Command on the FlashArray

Execute CLI Command on the FlashArray

Syntax 

Invoke-Pfa2CLICommand -CommandText <String> -Credential <PSCredential> -EndPoint <String> [-IgnoreCertificateError] [-TimeOutInMilliSeconds <Int32>] [<CommonParameters>]

Invoke-Pfa2CLICommand -CommandText <String> -EndPoint <String> [-IgnoreCertificateError] -Password <SecureString> [-TimeOutInMilliSeconds <Int32>] -UserName <String> [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-CommandText none The CLI command to run on the FlashArray true False None
-Credential none The credentials for SSH access to the FlashArray true True (ByValue) None
-EndPoint none The management address of the FlashArray true True (ByPropertyName) None
-IgnoreCertificateError none Prevents certificate errors such as an unknown certificate issuer or non-matching names from causing the request to fail. false False False
-Password none The SSH password for the FlashArray true False None
-TimeOutInMilliSeconds none Timeout in milliseconds false False None
-UserName none The SSH username for the FlashArray true False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • System.String System.Management.Automation.PSCredential

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
Invoke-Pfa2CLICommand -EndPoint $ArrayEndpoint -Username $ArrayUsername -Password $Password -CommandText $CommandText
Run a SSH cli command on FlashArray using Invoke-Pfa2CLICommand

-Name none Performs the operation on the unique name specified. false True (ByPropertyName, ByValue) None
-Password none Password associated with the account. false False None
-RoleName none Privilege level. Valid values include `array_admin`, `storage_admin`, and `readonly`. false False None

Top of page

New-Pfa2ApiClient

Create an API client

Creates an API client. Newly created API clients are disabled by default. Enable an API client through the `PATCH` method. The `Name`, `max_role`, `issuer`, and `public_key` parameters are required.

Syntax 

New-Pfa2ApiClient [-AccessTokenTtlInMs <Int64>] [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Issuer <String>] [-MaxRole <String>] [-Name <String>] [-PublicKey <String>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-AccessTokenTtlInMs none The TTL (Time To Live) length of time for the exchanged access token. Measured in milliseconds. If not specified, defaults to `86400000`. false False None
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Issuer none The name of the identity provider that will be issuing ID Tokens for this API client. The `iss` claim in the JWT issued must match this string. If not specified, defaults to the API client name. false False None
-MaxRole none The maximum role allowed for ID Tokens issued by this API client. The bearer of an access token will be authorized to perform actions within the intersection of this `max_role` and the role of the array user specified as the `sub`. Valid values are `array_admin`, `storage_admin`, `ops_admin`, and `readonly`. Users with the `readonly` (Read Only) role can perform operations that convey the state of the array. Read Only users cannot alter the state of the array. Users with the `ops_admin` (Ops Admin) role can perform the same operations as Read Only users plus enable and disable remote assistance sessions. Ops Admin users cannot alter the state of the array. Users with the `storage_admin` (Storage Admin) role can perform the same operations as Read Only users plus storage related operations, such as administering volumes, hosts, and host groups. Storage Admin users cannot perform operations that deal with global and system configurations. Users with the `array_admin` (Array Admin) role can perform the same operations as Storage Admin users plus array-wide changes dealing with global and system configurations. In other words, Array Admin users can perform all operations. false False None
-Name none Performs the operation on the unique name specified. false True (ByPropertyName, ByValue) None
-PublicKey none The API client's PEM formatted (Base64 encoded) RSA public key. Include the `-----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY-----` and `-----END PUBLIC KEY-----` lines. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • System.String

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
New-Pfa2ApiClient -Array $Array -MaxRole $MaxRole -Issuer $Issuer -PublicKey $Certificate -Name $ClientName
Create API client on FlashArray with maxrole as "array_admin" and name as $ClientName

Top of page

New-Pfa2ArrayAuth

Create an API Client

Create an API Client registration on an array for OAuth2 authentication

Syntax 

New-Pfa2ArrayAuth [-AccessTokenTtlMilliSeconds <Int64>] -ApiClientName <String> -Credential <PSCredential> -Endpoint <String> [-Force] -Issuer <String> [-MaxRole <String>] [<CommonParameters>]

New-Pfa2ArrayAuth [-AccessTokenTtlMilliSeconds <Int64>] -ApiClientName <String> -Endpoint <String> [-Force] -Issuer <String> [-MaxRole <String>] -Password <SecureString> -Username <String> [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-AccessTokenTtlMilliSeconds none Access token time-to-live duration, in milliseconds. false False None
-ApiClientName none A user-specified name. The name must be locally unique and cannot be changed. true False None
-Credential none The credentials for the FlashArray login. true True (ByValue) None
-Endpoint none The FlashArray name or IP address. true False None
-Force none Overwrites an existing ApiClient on the FlashArray if certificates are not found on the local machine. false False False
-Issuer none The name of the identity provider that will be issuing ID Tokens for this API client. This string represents the JWT iss (issuer) claim in ID Tokens issued for this API client. true False None
-MaxRole none The maximum role allowed for ID Tokens issued by this API client. The bearer of an access token will be authorized to perform actions within the intersection of this max_role and the role of the array user specified as the JWT sub (subject) claim. Valid max_role values are readonly, ops_admin, array_admin, and storage_admin. Users with the readonly (Read Only) role can perform operations that convey the state of the array. Read Only users cannot alter the state of the array. Users with the ops_admin (Ops Admin) role can perform the same operations as Read Only users plus enable and disable remote assistance sessions. Ops Admin users cannot alter the state of the array. Users with the storage_admin (Storage Admin) role can perform the same operations as Read Only users plus storage related operations, such as administering volumes, hosts, and host groups. Storage Admin users cannot perform operations that deal with global and system configurations. Users with the array_admin (Array Admin) role can perform the same operations as Storage Admin users plus array-wide changes dealing with global and system configurations. In other words, Array Admin users can perform all operations. false False None
-Password none Password associated with the login name of the array user. true False None
-Username none Login name of the array user for whom the token should be issued. This must be a valid user in the system. true False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • System.Management.Automation.PSCredential

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • PureStorage.Rest.PureApiClientAuthInfo

Examples

Example 1 
New-Pfa2ArrayAuth -Endpoint $endpoint -ApiClientName $clientName -Issuer $issuer -Username $arrayUsername -Password $psw
Create a new API client on FlashArray. The $ClientName must be unique per API client.

New-Pfa2ChapObject

Create an object of type Chap

Create a Chap object

Syntax 

New-Pfa2ChapObject [-HostPassword <String>] [-HostUser <String>] [-TargetPassword <String>] [-TargetUser <String>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-HostPassword none The host password for CHAP authentication. The password must be between 12 and 255 characters (inclusive) and cannot be the same as the target password. false False None
-HostUser none The host username for CHAP authentication. false False None
-TargetPassword none The target password for CHAP authentication. The password must be between 12 and 255 characters (inclusive) and cannot be the same as the host password. false False None
-TargetUser none The target username for CHAP authentication. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • None

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
New-Pfa2ChapObject -HostPassword "$(GetGuidName)" -HostUser $chapName -TargetPassword "$(GetGuidName)" -TargetUser $chapName
Create a new Chap object with parameters of HostPassword, HostUser, TargetPassword, and TargetUser, Chap object could be used as a parameter of New-Pfa2Host

Top of page

New-Pfa2Connection

Create a connection between a volume and host or host group

Creates a connection between a volume and a host or host group. The `VolumeNames` and `HostNames` or `HostGroupNames` query parameters are required.

Syntax 

New-Pfa2Connection [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-HostGroupNames <List<String>>] [-HostNames <List<String>>] [-Lun <Int32>] [-ProtocolEndpoint <Reference>] [-VolumeNames <List<String>>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-HostGroupNames none Performs the operation on the host group specified. Enter multiple names in comma-separated format. A request cannot include a mix of multiple objects with multiple names. For example, a request cannot include a mix of multiple host group names and volume names; instead, at least one of the objects (e.g., `HostGroupNames`) must be set to only one name (e.g., `hgroup01`). false False None
-HostNames none Performs the operation on the hosts specified. Enter multiple names in comma-separated format. For example, `host01,host02`. A request cannot include a mix of multiple objects with multiple names. For example, a request cannot include a mix of multiple host names and volume names; instead, at least one of the objects (e.g., `HostNames`) must be set to only one name (e.g., `host01`). false False None
-Lun none The logical unit number (LUN) by which the specified hosts are to address the specified volume. If the LUN is not specified, the system automatically assigns a LUN to the connection. To automatically assign a LUN to a private connection, the system starts at LUN `1` and counts up to the maximum LUN `4095`, assigning the first available LUN to the connection. For shared connections, the system starts at LUN `254` and counts down to the minimum LUN `1`, assigning the first available LUN to the connection. If all LUNs in the `[1...254]` range are taken, the system starts at LUN `255` and counts up to the maximum LUN `4095`, assigning the first available LUN to the connection. false False None
-ProtocolEndpoint none A protocol endpoint (also known as a conglomerate volume) which acts as a proxy through which virtual volumes are created and then connected to VMware ESXi hosts or host groups. The protocol endpoint itself does not serve I/Os; instead, its job is to form connections between FlashArray volumes and ESXi hosts and host groups. false False None
-VolumeNames none Performs the operation on the volume specified. Enter multiple names in comma-separated format. For example, `vol01,vol02`. A request cannot include a mix of multiple objects with multiple names. For example, a request cannot include a mix of multiple volume names and host names; instead, at least one of the objects (e.g., `VolumeNames`) must be set to only one name (e.g., `vol01`). false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • None

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
New-Pfa2Connection -Array $Array -HostNames $Host_.Name -VolumeNames $Volume.Name
Create a connection between volume $Volume.Name and host $Host_.Name
Example 2 
New-Pfa2Connection -Array $Array -HostGroupNames $HostGroup.Name -VolumeNames $Volume.Name
Create a connection between volume $Volume.Name and host group $HostGroup.Name

New-Pfa2FixedReferenceObject

Create an object of type FixedReference

Create a FixedReference object. The object is a reference to a specific target, which contains the field of Id and Name. For example, New-Pfa2TagObject allows user to create a tag object with resource by passing the Resource parameter. The parameter accepts type of FixedReference, which could be created from this cmdlet

Syntax 

New-Pfa2FixedReferenceObject [-Id <String>] [-Name <String>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-Id none A globally unique, system-generated ID. The ID cannot be modified. false False None
-Name none The resource name, such as volume name, pod name, snapshot name, and so on. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • None

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
New-Pfa2FixedReferenceObject -Id "TestResourceId" -Name "TestResourceName"
Create a new FixedReference object with parameter of Id and name, FixedReference object could be used as a parameter of New-Pfa2TagObject

Top of page

New-Pfa2Host

Create a host

Creates a host. The `Name` query parameter is required.

Syntax 

New-Pfa2Host [-ApiVersion <String>] [-Array <Rest2Api>] [-Chap <Chap>] [-Iqns <List<String>>] [-Name <String>] [-Nqns <List<String>>] [-Personality <String>] [-PreferredArrays <System.Collections.Generic.List`1[PureStorage.FlashArray.Rest.Model.Reference]>] [-Wwns <List<String>>] [<CommonParameters>]

Parameters

Name Alias Description Required? Pipeline Input Default Value
-ApiVersion none alternative API version false False None
-Array none The PureArray object representing a connection to a Pure Storage FlashArray. Created using the `Connect-Pfa2Array` cmdlet. false False None
-Chap none Challenge-Handshake Authentication Protocol (CHAP). false False None
-Iqns none The iSCSI qualified name (IQN) associated with the host. false False None
-Name none Performs the operation on the unique name specified. false True (ByPropertyName, ByValue) None
-Nqns none The NVMe Qualified Name (NQN) associated with the host. false False None
-Personality none Determines how the system tunes the array to ensure that it works optimally with the host. Set `personality` to the name of the host operating system or virtual memory system. Valid values are `aix`, `esxi`, `hitachi-vsp`, `hpux`, `oracle-vm-server`, `solaris`, and `vms`. If your system is not listed as one of the valid host personalities, do not set the option. By default, the personality is not set. false False None
-PreferredArrays none For synchronous replication configurations, sets a host's preferred array to specify which array exposes active/optimized paths to that host. Enter multiple preferred arrays in comma-separated format. If a preferred array is set for a host, then the other arrays in the same pod will expose active/non-optimized paths to that host. If the host is in a host group, `preferred_arrays` cannot be set because host groups have their own preferred arrays. On a preferred array of a certain host, all the paths on all the ports (for both the primary and secondary controllers) are set up as A/O (active/optimized) paths, while on a non-preferred array, all the paths are A/N (Active/Non-optimized) paths. false False None
-Wwns none The Fibre Channel World Wide Name (WWN) associated with the host. false False None

Inputs

The input type is the type of the objects that you can pipe to the cmdlet.

  • System.String

Outputs

The output type is the type of the objects that the cmdlet emits.

  • System.Object

Examples

Example 1 
New-Pfa2Host -Array $Array -Name "$(GetGuidName)"
Create a new host on FlashArray with name "$(GetGuidName)"
Example 2 
New-Pfa2Host -Array $Array -Name $HostName -iqns $iqns -nqns $nqns -wwns $wwns -chap $chap
Create a new host with parameters of Name, iqns, nqns, wwns, and chap. Chap object can be created with New-Pfa2ChapObject cmdlet.

Top of page
